speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about the swelling on your neck? When did it start and has it changed in size or shape over time?

speaker: Patient
text: It started about two months ago, and I'd say it's been steadily getting bigger. I've noticed it's not really changing shape, but it feels a bit... hard to the touch, like a lump.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your daily activities? Have you been doing any strenuous exercises, lifting heavy objects, or experiencing any recent trauma that could have caused the swelling?

speaker: Patient
text: To be honest, I've been doing the usual stuff – working as a traffic warden, playing golf on weekends, and taking care of my diabetes and hypertension. Nothing too strenuous, I don't think. Although, I did have a bit of a fall while walking my dog a week ago, but it was just a minor tumble and I didn't think much of it at the time.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you take off your shirt and let me examine the swelling more closely? I'd like to check for any tenderness or warmth around the lump.

speaker: Patient
text: I'll just remove my shirt for you. *removes shirt, exposing the swelling* It's a bit awkward, but I'll try to relax as much as I can.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you show me exactly where the swelling is located on your neck, and is it centered or more to one side?

speaker: Patient
text: It's located on the nape of my neck, just above the collarbone, I think. It's kind of centered, but if I had to guess, it's a bit more to the left side.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me if the swelling is painful or tender to the touch, even when you're not pressing on it?

speaker: Patient
text: It's not really painful, but it does feel a bit firm to the touch, like I mentioned earlier. When you press on it, it's a bit uncomfortable, but I wouldn't say it's excruciating or anything.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your diabetes and hypertension management? Have you noticed any changes in your medication regimen or blood sugar levels recently? Also, I'd like to request a blood pressure reading to confirm your current levels.

speaker: Patient
text: I've been taking the same medication for years, just adjusting the dose of insulin glargine every few months to keep my blood sugar levels in check. I've also been taking metformin as prescribed, and my doctor has been monitoring my blood pressure with enalapril. I don't recall any recent changes in my medication regimen, but I do get regular check-ups to keep an eye on everything. Please go ahead and take my blood pressure reading, I'll stay still for you.

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your symptoms since the fall while walking your dog? Have you experienced any pain or discomfort in your neck, shoulder, or arm that could be related to the swelling? Also, I'd like to request a blood pressure reading to confirm your current levels.

speaker: Patient
text: I did notice a bit of discomfort in my neck and shoulder area right after the fall, but it's been pretty much gone since then. I just chalked it up to a minor strain or something. My blood pressure is usually around 130/85, but I'm happy to take another reading for you.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to request a blood pressure reading again to confirm your current levels. Can you also tell me if you've experienced any recent weight loss or gain, as this can sometimes be associated with certain conditions? Also, I'd like to examine the swelling further. Can you gently turn your head to the right, so I can get a better look at the swelling from the side?

speaker: Patient
text: I'm happy to oblige with the blood pressure reading again. *takes blood pressure reading, which comes in at 130/85* As for weight loss or gain, I've noticed I've been eating a bit more than usual lately, probably due to stress from work. I've also been trying to balance my diet more since my doctor told me to take better care of myself, but I'm not sure if that's had any significant impact yet. And sure, I can turn my head to the right. *turns head to the right, exposing the swelling from the side*

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your diet and eating habits, specifically the foods you've been consuming that might be contributing to the swelling? Also, I'd like to request an X-ray of the cervical spine to get a better look at the swelling from a different angle. And, I'd like to take a closer look at the swelling, can you gently tilt your head to the left so I can examine it from the front?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been trying to eat more healthily, like my doctor suggested. I've been focusing on fruits, vegetables, and whole grains, but I do have a bit of a weakness for sweets and pasta dishes. I've also been trying to cut back on processed foods and sugars, but I'm not sure if that's making a big difference yet. I'll go ahead and tilt my head to the left for you. *tilts head to the left, exposing the swelling from the front* And, if it's not too much trouble, I'd be happy to have that X-ray done. I'm just curious to see what's going on under the surface, you know?

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your diet and eating habits, specifically the foods you've been consuming that might be contributing to the swelling? You mentioned sweets and pasta dishes, have you noticed any recent changes in your consumption of these types of foods? And I'll go ahead and request the X-ray of the cervical spine, as well as an MRI of the neck to get a better look at the swelling. REQUEST TEST: Cervical_X-Ray, REQUEST TEST: Neck_MRI Also, I'd like to examine the swelling further. Can you gently bring your hands up to your ears, so I can check for any tenderness or warmth around the area?

speaker: Measurement
text: RESULTS: Vital Signs: - Temperature: 37.3°C (99.1°F) - Blood Pressure: 130/86 mm Hg - Heart Rate: 88/min - Respiratory Rate: Normal Neck Examination: - Inspection and Palpation: A 2.5-cm (1-in) firm, mobile, painless nodule on the nape of the neck. The skin over the nodule cannot be pinched. - Other Findings: No lymphadenopathy or thyromegaly. Lung Examination: - Auscultation: Clear lungs bilaterally, no rales, rhonchi, or wheezes. Remainder of the Examination: - Findings: No abnormalities. tests: - Imaging: - Ultrasound of the Neck: - Findings: Well-circumscribed lesion in the subcutaneous tissue suggestive of a cystic nature. - Complete Blood Count: - WBC: Normal - Hemoglobin: Normal - Platelets: Normal - Serum Chemistry: - Glucose: Elevated - Creatinine: Normal - Liver Enzymes: Normal

speaker: Doctor
text: It seems like the swelling is quite firm and mobile, and the ultrasound suggests a cystic nature. I'd like to ask a few more questions to help narrow down the possibilities. Can you tell me more about the sensation of the swelling, is it warm to the touch or does it feel like it's moving around under the skin? Also, I'd like to request the MRI results to get a better look at the swelling and rule out any other potential causes. REQUEST TEST: Neck_MRI And one more thing, have you noticed any changes in your vision or hearing recently, as some conditions can cause swelling in the neck to affect these senses?

speaker: Doctor
text: Can you tell me more about your symptoms since the urinalysis results came back normal? Have you noticed any changes in your urination habits or frequency since we discussed your increased urination? Also, I'd like to review the Neck_MRI report and see if we can get a better understanding of the swelling. Can you bring me the report now?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been going to the bathroom just as often as usual, but I did notice that I've been urinating a bit more frequently at night, maybe because of the swelling or something. I'm not sure if it's related, but I've also been feeling a bit more thirsty than usual, which could be a side effect of the elevated glucose levels, I suppose.

speaker: Doctor
text: I'd like to review the Neck_MRI report now. Can you bring me the report and let's take a look at the swelling together? Also, I'd like to request that you continue to monitor your urination habits and report back to me if you notice any further changes. Can you tell me more about the Neck_MRI report? Are there any abnormalities that you think might be related to the swelling? Also, I'd like to ask one more question. Have you noticed any changes in your overall energy levels or physical activity since the swelling started?

speaker: Patient
text: I've been feeling a bit more sluggish than usual, to be honest. I've been trying to keep up with my usual golf games, but I have to admit, I'm not as energetic as I used to be. It's not that I'm not enjoying myself, it's just that I feel like I'm working a bit harder to keep up, you know?

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like the swelling is affecting your overall energy levels and physical activity. I'd like to ask one more question about the Neck_MRI report. Are there any abnormalities that you think might be related to the swelling? Specifically, are there any signs of compression or damage to the surrounding nerves or tissues? Also, I'd like to request that you continue to monitor your urination habits and report back to me if you notice any further changes. We'll keep a close eye on this to rule out any underlying conditions that might be contributing to the swelling. Can you tell me more about your golf games? Have you noticed any changes in your swing or technique since the swelling started?

speaker: Patient
text: I've noticed that my swing isn't as smooth as it used to be, and I've had to adjust my technique a bit to compensate for the feeling of the swelling. I'm not sure if it's just my mind playing tricks on me, but it feels like it's affecting my balance and coordination a bit.

speaker: Doctor
text: It sounds like the swelling is affecting your golf swing and overall balance and coordination. I'd like to ask one more question to help narrow down the possibilities. Have you noticed any numbness, tingling, or weakness in your arms or hands, especially when you're swinging or moving your arms? Also, I'd like to request that you continue to monitor your urination habits and report back to me if you notice any further changes. We'll keep a close eye on this to rule out any underlying conditions that might be contributing to the swelling. Please let me know if you have any further questions or concerns. I'll do my best to help you get to the bottom of this. (Still waiting for the Neck_MRI report to be available)

text: I've been noticing that when I look to the left side, it feels like the swelling is slightly more prominent, and I can feel it pressing against my shoulder blade. I'm not sure if it's just my imagination, but it's definitely noticeable.
